content.description: Sit start and climb through powerful crimps, with a tricky final sequence to topout on a ledge 3/4 up the boulder.
content.location: West side of the Hood. This climb is on the shorter side of a very tall boulder and is one of the first problems you pass, just before the trail cuts downhill to the Acid Rain boulder.

content.description: Sit start and make the first awkward move up the crisp arete. Continue up and right, topping out on either side of the arete.
content.location: West side of the Hood. A couple hundred feet immediately downhill from the ripple problem.

content.description: Sit start using a good right hand jug and any left hand. Cross up to a jug, then work your way up and right on sloping edges. Gain the juggy pocket, then continue right through progressively harder moves until you can reach the good crimp just below the lip. Top out on the top-right corner.
content.location: West side of the Hood, immediately down hill from "Breaking All Illusions."

content.description: Layback up the column until you reach the break. Shake off the stage fright, hug the wall, and dance your way to the chains.
content.protection: 4 bolts to chain anchor; All hardware is stainless
content.location: Right side of the first cliff approached from the trail.

content.description:
Open project up the steep face to the left of the waterfall in the first amphitheater.

 The bottom is comprised of 3 separate dynos. The first and third are doable. The second is the crux of the route, and is hardly conceivable. An Arkansas boulderer's dream.
content.location: Two minutes past the initial drop down. The steep face to the left of the first waterfall in the first amphitheater.

content.description: A juggy start leads to technical face climbing that concludes at a good rest in the break below the roof. Clip the last bolt from a jug, then fire into the bouldery sequence. Stay sharp going for the chains, the jug on the left tends to get wet and the slopey holds can be tricky to see.
content.location: Climbs the center of the grey and orange wall, 5 minutes past the initial drop-down.

content.description: Get ready for long reaches between good holds! This one is difficult to read and will test your endurance.  Make sure to keep it together for the pumpy finish.
content.location: Third white stripe from the right on the Zebra Wall, 3 minutes past the initial sport climbing area.

content.description:
Stick clip recommended.

 Two ways to start, two ways to finish. Pick a line and go have a good time!

 The large break at the bottom of the route seeps, so it's best to bring a towel to wipe off the starting holds.

 The right variation begins with a mantel onto a large detached block, then rejoins the left line at a good resting jug. There is a rock stack that can be used to access a jug on the face of the large block, bypassing the seeping break and the sandy rock.
content.location: 10 minutes past the initial drop down. Just past the second running creek.

content.description:
Carbon Lives attacks a series of technical sequences through the face with the large crescent rail and finishes on the overhang just to the right of the black, seasonally wet rock.

 Begin with easy climbing to reach the high first bolt. Tick tack your way through techy face sequences broken up by good rests. After the crescent rail, clip the third bolt and fire into the boulder problem. Make it to the jug and earn the 4th bolt. Regain your energy at the ledge, then hold on for the last few moves to the chains.

 Although there tends to be a lot of runoff/seepage around this route, the holds usually stay dry even after a rain. At the 5th and 6th bolts there are a lot of wet holds, but the dry holds are there if you look/feel around. Sometimes the dry holds are behind the wetness...

 A fixed steel draw has been left on the fifth bolt to aid in cleaning and to allow climbers an opportunity to bail, should the final holds be wet.

 Note: The line climbs right at the third bolt to avoid the seasonally wet rock to the left. There is potential here for an easier variation if the holds ever dry out.
content.protection: 5 bolts to traditional anchor. 5th draw is fixed.
content.location: This wall is a 5 minute hike from the initial drop-down to the Hood. This is the line to the left of the two small huecos/impressions in the face (near the 2nd and 3rd bolts).

content.description: AKA The Ripple ProblemBegin with an awkward, dabby, low sit start. Crimp your way up the perfect ripples to the top.
content.location: West side of the Hood, about a 10 minute walk from the drop-down on the standard approach. Located on a 9' cliff band to the left of a large amphitheater.

content.description: Sit start matched on the shelf. Traverse good holds left then set up for the reach to the crescent. More good holds lead to a sequential topout.
content.location: The first standalone boulder reached using the standard approach after the cave and initial cliff bands. The overhang is 10 feet tall, and the top is a large, slopey, featured slab.

content.description: Crouch start using two strange holds and pop your way up 2 big moves. Finish on Acid Rain. This one’s for the campus punks.
content.location: The first standalone boulder reached after the cave and initial cliffline. Shares a topout with Acid Rain.

content.description: Another often overlooked zone at Cowell, the Hood has long been missing the attention it deserves. There's no question why: up until 2019, this area only had 4 5.12s and no documented boulder problems. This barrier to entry is slowly being stripped away as new routes are developed and documented. With it's short approach and variety of styles and rock types, the Hood has something to offer for everybody.
